conclusion: Understand the problem setup with a copper rod in a magnetic field.
Copper rod MN with mass m and length L is suspended by two wires in a magnetic field B perpendicular to the paper.
Before energizing, tension in each wire is T = mg/2.
Magnetic force on a current-carrying conductor is F = ILB.
Using the right-hand rule, if current is from M to N, force is upward.
After energizing, new tension in each wire is T' = mg/8.
Net force on the rod is zero, so 2*(T') + F = mg.
Substitute T' = mg/8 and F = I L B into the equation.
Simplify to mg/4 + I L B = mg.
Confirm direction of current is from M to N since force is upward.
Consider both current directions to confirm upward force and reduced tension.
